docs.lead_paragraph: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Kindercare Learning Centers Inc., the nation's largest preschool and child care company, for approximately $467 million, or $20.25 a share. Kohlberg Kravis made the announcement along with Kindercare and Oaktree Capital Management L.L.C., a Los Angeles-based company that manages a 52 percent stake in Kindercare that is owned by TCW Special Credits, a unit of Trust Company of the West.

headline.main: Kohlberg Kravis Will Buy Kindercare for $467 Million

docs.abstract: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co says it has agreed to buy Kindercare Learning Centers Inc for $467 million, or $20.25 a share; Kohlbert Kravis makes announcement along with Kindercare and Oaktree Capital Management LLC, company that manages 52 percent stake in Kindercare owned by TCW Special Credits, unit of Trust Co of the West (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: When Californians lament ''the casualty of the day,'' they are not referring to victims of gang violence, drug abuse or reckless driving. Rather, they are referring to people injured or mistreated by health maintenance organizations. Nurses and consumer groups have disseminated many horror stories to support their demands for stricter state regulation of H.M.O.'s, as proposed in two measures on the ballot this November. Just as California led the nation in developing H.M.O.'s and other forms of managed care, it is now demonstrating the reaction that may set in when consumers conclude that the quality of care has been eroded by the pursuit of profits.

headline.main: Stakes High as California Debates Ballot Issues to Rein In H.M.O.'s

docs.abstract: California, which led nation in developing health maintenance organizations, is placing two initiatives on ballot in Nov that would ban practices that HMO's have used or been accused of using to control costs; proposals would outlaw bonuses and other financial incentives for doctors to withhold treatment, prohibit HMO's from limiting what doctors may tell patients and require HMO's to disclose all written criteria for denial of care (M)
docs.snippet: When Californians lament ''the casualty of the day,'' they are not referring to victims of gang violence, drug abuse or reckless driving. Rather, they are referring to people injured or mistreated by health maintenance organizations.    Nurses and...

docs.lead_paragraph: Valerie Yerdon talks in a flat voice with no hint of emotion, describing how she lost the middle finger and index finger of her right hand. She was cleaning the side of a printing press with a rag when the press's high-speed rollers pulled in the rag, and her fingers along with it.

headline.main: Labor Strife and Amputations Roil a Plastics Factory

docs.abstract: Landis Plastics employee Valerie Yerdon lost middle and index fingers of her right hand in accident when she was cleaning side of printing press; she declines to fault Solvay, NY, company, but many of her co-workers, along with some clergymen and safety experts, have harsh words for Landis's safety record and other unpleasant aspects of work there; police reports show that in last 15 months, three other employees at 200-worker factory have lost fingers on job; Federal Occupational Safety and Health Administration is investigating Landis for failing to report many injuries in its safety logs, as required by law; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Valerie Yerdon talks in a flat voice with no hint of emotion, describing how she lost the middle finger and index finger of her right hand.    She was cleaning the side of a printing press with a rag when the press's high-speed rollers pulled in the...

docs.lead_paragraph: Furthering the trend toward consolidation in managed care, two big California providers, the Foundation Health Corporation and Health Systems International, announced what they called a merger of equals yesterday, in the process creating a $6.4 billion company with nearly five million members. Under the terms of the all-stock transaction, which the companies valued at approximately $3 billion, Foundation will merge and become a subsidiary of Health Systems, and Health Systems will change its name to Foundation Health Systems.

headline.main: Big Merger Set In Health Care For California

docs.abstract: Foundation Health Corp and Health Systems International, two large managed care providers in California, announce what they call merger of equals; under terms of all-stock transaction, which companies value at about $3 billion, foundation will merge and become subsidiary of Health Systems, and Health Systems will change its name to Foundation Health Systems; analysts say merger makes sense, particularly in California, nation's most competitive market for managed health care services; merger was hastened by August alliance of FHP International Corp and Pacificare Health Systems, two other California companies; although called merger of equals, Health Systems would appear to be acquiring foundation; after serving for year as chairman of new entity, Daniel D Crowley, Foundation Health's chairman and chief executive, will step down and turn job over to Malik M Hasan, chief executive of Health Systems (M)
docs.snippet: Furthering the trend toward consolidation in managed care, two big California providers, the Foundation Health Corporation and Health Systems International, announced what they called a merger of equals yesterday, in the process creating a $6.4...

docs.lead_paragraph: In the latest salvo in the battle for the growing New York-area health care market, Anthem Inc., a big insurance holding company based in the Midwest, confirmed yesterday that it planned to add Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Connecticut to its Anthem East unit. Anthem and the Blue Cross plan said yesterday they had agreed in principle to merge, subject to approval by the Anthem board at a meeting this week and by insurance commissioners in Connecticut and Indiana, Anthem's home state. Since the partners are mutual insurance companies, the deal is also subject to approval by their policyholders.

headline.main: Deal Confirmed for Blue Cross of Connecticut

docs.abstract: Anthem Inc, big insurance company based in Indiana, confirms it plans to add Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Connecticut to its Anthem East unit; says Anthem and Blue Cross will merge, subject to approval by Anthem board and insurance commissioners in Connecticut and Indiana; deal, in which no cash changes hands, will unite Anthem with a Blue Cross and Blue Shield plan rich in customers, if not in profits; Anthem East would also include Blue Cross and Blue Shield in New Jersey and Delaware, plans Anthem is in process of acquiring; health care experts say Anthem will eventually compete head on with giant Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield in New York (M)
docs.snippet: In the latest salvo in the battle for the growing New York-area health care market, Anthem Inc., a big insurance holding company based in the Midwest, confirmed yesterday that it planned to add Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Connecticut to its Anthem...

docs.lead_paragraph: As President Clinton bids the departing Republican 104th Congress godspeed and good riddance, he can reflect on having shared more legislative success with it than with the Democratic 103d Congress. It has hardly been a cheery, backslapping partnership. Mr. Clinton calls the Republican agenda a ''Contract on America,'' designed to wreck Medicare and a variety of other domestic programs. Speaker Newt Gingrich drips contempt as he labels the President ''dishonest,'' and even more carefully spoken Republicans do not hide the exasperation behind their civility.

headline.main: The President and Congress: A Partnership of Self-Interest

docs.abstract: Adam Clymer assesses Pres Clinton's record in terms of his relationship with Congress; sees partnership as one of self-interest; observes that as Clinton bids departing Republican 104th Congress godspeed and good riddance, he can reflect on having shared more legislative success with it than with Democratic 103d Congress (M)
docs.snippet: As President Clinton bids the departing Republican 104th Congress godspeed and good riddance, he can reflect on having shared more legislative success with it than with the Democratic 103d Congress.    It has hardly been a cheery, backslapping...

docs.lead_paragraph: Elderly people and poor people who are chronically ill tend to fare worse in health maintenance organizations, which pay a flat rate for each patient, than in conventional insurance plans, which pay doctors for each service, researchers reported today. The researchers, led by John E. Ware Jr. of the New England Medical Center in Boston, said that for average patients there was no particular difference between the outcomes of treatment by H.M.O.'s and fee-for-service plans.

headline.main: Elderly and Poor Do Worse Under H.M.O. Plans' Care

docs.abstract: Researchers report that elderly people and poor people who are chronically ill tend to fare worse in health maintenance orgns, which pay flat rate for each patient, then in conventional insurance plans, which pay doctors for each service (M)
docs.snippet: Elderly people and poor people who are chronically ill tend to fare worse in health maintenance organizations, which pay a flat rate for each patient, than in conventional insurance plans, which pay doctors for each service, researchers reported...

docs.lead_paragraph: NEW YORK Kmart Meets the Enemy From the Manhattan-centered view of the universe, Kmart has long been one of the big symbols of the world Out There, a caricature of strip mall culture at its height, or depth. Kmart, in turn, ignored Manhattan completely. Manhattan was antithesis, everything that Kmart was not, lacking everything that had made the Kmart formula work everywhere else. Now, Manhattan has become a critical element in the company's plans for a rebirth. $(Page A1.$) Steinbrenner's Quiet Side As the Yankees prepared for the playoffs, at least part of the jabber among the city's jabbering baseball fans was about George M. Steinbrenner 3d, the team's principal owner, who -- unlike previous years -- has let his manager and general manager do the talking for the team. The question is: Has he mellowed? $(B1.$) New Challenge on Welfare Law Mayor Giuliani significantly broadened his attack on the new Federal welfare law, saying that the denial of social services to legal immigrants was both morally wrong and unconstitutional. The Mayor accused Congress and President Clinton of trying to limit immigration by making the lives of immigrants miserable. $(B1.$) Thirteen months before he seeks re-election, the Mayor is leading his potential rivals, a poll finds. $(B7.$) In Central Park, a Hunt After selling both their vacation homes to consolidate their lives in the city, George and Catherine Parry longed for the water sports they both love. Then, as they gazed upon the Central Park Reservoir from their Fifth Avenue apartment, the couple hit upon an idea to fill the void. Wearing full scuba gear, they are working to clear more than a century's worth of garbage from the reservoir. $(B1.$) Soup Kitchens in a Struggle The Rev. William Greenlaw can't really explain it, but for about the last six weeks -- coincidentally or not the period since President Clinton signed the welfare-overhaul law -- lines have grown a lot longer at the soup kitchen he runs out of the Episcopal Church of the Holy Apostles. Even before the sweeping changes, soup kitchens and pantries were struggling to keep pace with a sharp rise in demand. NYC by Clyde Haberman. $(B1.$) Criticism Among Labor Leaders Stanley Hill, the head of the city's largest municipal union was criticized by fellow labor leaders for failing to win more concessions from Mayor Giuliani before the city expands its workfare program. $(B3.$) School Ready for Opening Day Nearly three weeks after building violations forced the delay of classes at the High School for Cooperative Technical Education, the school is ready to open. $(B3.$) Editor Leaves The Daily News Martin Dunn, the top editor of The Daily News, is leaving the paper, becoming the latest of several senior editors to depart since Mortimer B. Zuckerman bought the tabloid in 1993. No successor was named. $(B3.$) Guard Testifies in Fisher Suit Testifying in a civil suit, a prison guard denied allegations that they had an affair with Amy Fisher in 1993. Miss Fisher, who is serving 5 to 15 years for shooting the wife of a former boyfriend, Joey Buttafuoco, has sued to be transferred to the Federal prison system. $(B5.$) Criticism on City Contracts The City Comptroller raised new questions about how the Giuliani administration awards millions of dollars in contracts, contending that mental health officials had ignored guidelines intended to prevent mismanagement and patronage. City Hall said the criticism was inaccurate. $(B6.$) Arraignment in Child's Death Carla Lockwood pleaded not guilty to murder charges stemming from the starvation death of her 4-year-old daughter, Nadine. $(B7.$) CONNECTICUT Jury Selection in Rape Trial Lawyers for Alex Kelly, the onetime high school wrestling star who fled to Europe when he was charged with raping two teen-age girls a decade ago, are to begin selecting a jury for a trial of one of the rape cases. Mr. Kelly faces new charges stemming from a car accident. $(B5.$) 2 Held in Attempted Kidnapping A former Green Beret colonel who served as a mediator in the Freemen standoff in Montana was arrested on charges that he tried to kidnap a middle school student in Suffield. His son was also charged. $(B7.$) Blue Cross Merger Expected Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Connecticut has agreed to merge with Anthem Inc., a big Midwestern insurance company that is rapidly expanding across the country, people with knowledge of the deal said. The Connecticut insurer would become part of Anthem East Inc., based in Newark, along with Blue Cross and Blue Shield plans in New Jersey and Delaware. Business Day. $(D8.$) NEW JERSEY Double Killing in Englewood A retired psychiatrist and his wife, a social worker, were found stabbed to death in their home in a wealthy section of Englewood, and a man with a bloody shirt, described by investigators as their 30-year-old son, was being questioned. $(B5.$)

docs.lead_paragraph: Shrugging off wide-scale worker protests over the last few days, Germany's biggest industrial corporations plan to trim back some of the most generous employee benefits in the world. In a hard-line stance that marks a major departure from Germany's tradition of collaboration between management and labor, companies like Daimler-Benz, Siemens and the General Motors Corporation's Opel subsidiary plan to take advantage of a new law that goes into effect Tuesday and immediately cut sick pay by 20 percent -- even though their workers are covered by labor contracts that do not expire until later next year.

headline.main: New Hard Line by Big Companies Threatens German Work Benefits

docs.abstract: Germany's biggest industrial companies plan to trim back some of world's most generous employee benefits, taking advantage of new law to immediately cut sick pay by 20% even though labor contracts do not expire until next year; move, which shrugs off widescale labor protests, enrages unions and even startles Kohl Government; outcome will be closely watched, as French and Italian governments also propose laws to cut corporate costs and make Europe more competitive; Daimler-Benz chief executive Jurgen E Schrempp insists consensus system must be modified; German economy is groaning under strain of high labor costs, lavish vacation and sick pay benefits and rigid work rules; photo of protest by Mercedes workers; graph showing average sick days and benefits in western Europe (M)
